data.title: Langley, Arthur Austin (1859-1939)
data.meta_description: Arthur Austin Langley was a hotel operator. He lived at 2060 Comox Street from 1907 to 1909. He was at 1801 Nelson Street from 1910 to 1912, in 1915 and from 1921 to 1925. Arthur Austin Langley was born near Bath, Somerset, England on January 11, 1859. His parents were George Langley (1825-1899) and Martha…
data.text:
Arthur Austin Langley was a hotel operator. He lived at 2060 Comox Street from 1907 to 1909. He was at 1801 Nelson Street from 1910 to 1912, in 1915 and from 1921 to 1925.

Arthur Austin Langley was born near Bath, Somerset, England on January 11, 1859. His parents were George Langley (1825-1899) and Martha Maine (1816-1900).

About 1873, the Langley family moved to Essex County, Ontario.

In February 1882, in Essex County, Arthur married Leona Edna Broadwell. She was born in Essex, Ontario on January 31, 1865. Her parents were Joel Broadwell (1833-1909) and Mary Amanda Thompson (1836-1901).

Arthur and Leona travelled to Vancouver by way of San Francisco, California. They arrived in Vancouver on September 2, 1882.

By 1887, Arthur was a clerk at Brighton House hotel in Hastings, near the current site of New Brighton Park in Vancouver.

He lived at the following addresses in Vancouver.

1887 to 1888 Hasting (New Brighton) 1889 57 Cordova Street 1890 110 Carroll Street 1891 318 Carroll Street 1892 Not listed under Vancouver names 1894 515-515 Westminster Avenue 1895 and 1896 Not listed under Vancouver names 1897 and 1898 222 Carroll Street 1899 3 Cordova Street 1899 to 1901 222 Carroll Street 1902 852 Powell Street 1903 to 1906 898 Powell Street 1907 to 1909 2060 Comox Street (listed as 2070 Comox in 1909 Vancouver names) 1910 to 1912 1801 Nelson Street 1913 and 1914 Not listed under Vancouver names 1915 1801 Nelson Street 1916 Not listed under Vancouver names 1917 to 1920 1761 Davie Street 1921 to 1925 1801 Nelson Street 1926 Not listed under Vancouver names 1927 1763 Davie Street 1928 and 1929 1757 Davie Street 1930 to 1932 1761 Davie Street 1933 1757 Davie Street 1934 Not listed under Vancouver names 1935 and 1936 1600 Robson Street (possible connection) 1937 to 1939 1769 Robson Street

Arthur operated a series of hotels in Vancouver, including the Richmond, Glasgow, Boulder and Barnard Castle hotels.

After Arthur retired about 1907, he and Leona continued to live in Vancouver, although they travelled abroad from time to time.

Leona died in Vancouver on January 24, 1932.

Arthur died in Vancouver on October 15, 1939.

Arthur and Leona had a son.

Ellery George Langley

Ellery George Langley was born in Vancouver on February 6, 1890.

He studied at Upper Canada College in Ontario.

On June 20, 1911, in Vancouver, he married Helen (“Nell”) Ernestine Brenton.

Nell was born in Victoria, British Columbia, on April 4, 1890. Her parents were Rev. Charles John Brenton (1851-1909) and Mary Jeanette Phinney (1850-1921).

Ellery died in North Vancouver, British Columbia on December 10, 1958.

Nell died in North Vancouver on March 6, 1971.

Sources

George Langley (father of Arthur Austin Langley)

George Carey Langley, 1825 – 1899; https://www.myheritage.com/names/george_langley: “George Carey Langley, 1825 – 1899. George Carey Langley was born in month 1825, at [birth place], to Samuel Langley and Nancy Langley (born Carey). Samuel was born in August 1794, in Holcombe, Somerset, England. Nancy was born in August 1799, in Kilmersdon, Somerset, England. George married Martha Langley (born Maine) on date, at [marriage place]. Martha was born in 1816, in Camerton, Somerset, England. They had one son: Arthur Austin Langley. George passed away on month day 1899, at age 73 at [death place].

Arthur Austin Langley

Major James Skitt Matthews, Early Vancouver, Vol. 5 (Vancouver: City of Vancouver, 2011), page 7; http://former.vancouver.ca/ctyclerk/archives/digitized/EarlyVan/SearchEarlyVan/Vol5pdf/MatthewsEarlyVancouverVol5_MemoOfConversationArthurAustinLangley20Feb1936.pdf:

“Memo of Conversation with Arthur Austin Langley, 20 February 1936. Born seven miles from Bath, Somerset, England, 11 January 1859 (now 77 years old), of 1600 Robson Street, widower, where he lives with his deceased wife’s sister, who is aged 70. Mr. Langley is the youngest child of the large family of George and Martha Langley, who came to Canada in June 1873 on the S.S. Aragon from Bristol to New York and then to Essex County, Ontario. He was the youngest of a family of ten, and some of his elder brothers had preceded them to Kingsville, Ontario. The family went farming; Mr. Langley did not go to school in Canada after his arrival at the age of 14.

. . .

Mr. Langley said: “After our arrival in Canada, I started working for a butcher, afterwards my wife’s father—Miss Leona Broadwell; we were married in Essex County, and the next day, 6th February 1882, we left, together with my wife’s family—Broadwell—to come to British Columbia. The Broadwells settled, they did not pre-empt, but bought, on Salt Spring Island in 1882. Both are deceased now. My wife and I came to Gastown on 1st September 1882, to work in George Black’s butcher shop which was over the water next door to the Sunnyside Hotel. He had an ordinary row boat fitted up, not with a butcher block, as some say, but with a meat cutting board; most of the meat had been cut up in the shop over the water on what is now Water Street. We took the meat to the Moodyville Mill and the ships twice a week.”

“England and Wales Birth Registration Index, 1837-2008,” database, FamilySearch (https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:26RY-JKF : 1 October 2014), Arthur Langley, 1859; from “England & Wales Births, 1837-2006,” database, findmypast (http://www.findmypast.com : 2012); citing Birth Registration, Clutton, Somerset, England, citing General Register Office, Southport, England. [possible connection].
